questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive woman visits the clinic with complaints of memory loss. CD4 count done at that time showed it was 50. A couple of months later, the patient dies and autopsy of the brain showed demyelination. The most likely co-infection was?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario of HIV patient with low CD4 count, complaints of memory loss, and demyelination on autopsy, the disease is progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy(PML) caused by JC virus.

PML is a fatal subacute progressive demyelinating disease caused by the neurotrophic JC polyomavirus. It is an opportunistic infection that usually occurs at CD4 counts less than 200 per microliter.

The image below shows brain biopsy of a Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy case showing Oligodendrocytes with SV40 positive inclusions indicative of JC Virus infection (SV40 Immunohistochemistry, brown)

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as:
questions.solution:
The Declaration of Oslo (1970) is related to therapeutic abortion.

Other options:

  • Declaration of Alma-Ata: Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All
  • Declaration of Tokyo: related to torture and other degradation
  • Declaration of Helsinki: concerned with Human experimentation.

Related Pearl: Health-related International Declarations:

  1. Declaration of Alma-Ata (1978): Identified primary health care as the key to the attainment of the goal of Health for All.
  2. Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion (1986): The aim of the conference was to continue to  achieve the objectives of the World Health Organization (WHO) Health for all by the year 2000.

3. Declaration of Oslo (1970): Related to therapeutic abortion.

4. Declaration of Tokyo (1975): Guidelines for medical doctors concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment in relation to detention and imprisonment. (T – Tokyo – Torture)

5. Declaration of Helsinki (1975): Related to human experimentation. (H – Helsinki – Human experimentation)

6. Declaration of Geneva (1948): Most recent amendment was done on October 14, 2017 in Chicago. It gives the modern version of the 2500-year-old Hippocratic Oath which laid down the fundamental principles of medical ethics that any physician should follow.

7. Declaration of Malta (1991, revised in 1992): Related to hunger strikes.

8. Declaration of Lisbon: Related to rights of the patients like right to information, confidentiality, dignity, freedom of choice etc.

9. Declaration of Sydney on human death: It stated that the determination of death “will be based on clinical judgment, supplemented if necessary by a number of diagnostic aids”, emphasising the EEG. Nonetheless, it asserted that “the overall judgment of the physician” could not be replaced by any ancillary test.

The statement also recommended that two or more physicians should make the diagnosis of death when organs were removed for transplantation.

10. Declaration of Istanbul: To address the urgent and growing problems of organ sales, transplant tourism and trafficking in organ donors in the context of the global shortage of organs.

11. Declaration of Taipei: Related to ethical considerations regarding health databases and biobanks.

questions.text: A carpenter was hammering a nail into a door. Accidentally, he struck his left thumb with the hammer. He developed a lasting, throbbing pain. What is the type of nerve fibre carrying this pain and its rate of conduction, respectively?
questions.solution:
The throbbing pain experienced after a strike with a hammer on the nail of the left thumb is a deep throbbing pain (slow, dull aching, and second pain) and it is carried by C – fibres (conducting at a rate of 0.5–2 m/s). (Neurotransmitters – Glutamate and Substance P).

Other Options:

Aδ fibre conducts “fast, first pain” at a rate of 12–35 m/s. (Neurotransmitter – Glutamate)

Related Pearl: Dual Pain Pathway

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia was brought to the hospital with acute onset of neck stiffness. On examination, his upper body and neck are rigid. On review of his medications, it is seen that he has been started on haloperidol 5 days back. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the history of recent haloperidol usage the most probable diagnosis is acute dystonia. 

Treatment: anticholinergics, such as benztropine, diphenhydramine, or trihexyphenidyl.

Other options:

  • Akathisia: Extrapyramidal syndrome characterized by a feeling of restlessness, frequent repetitive stereotyped movements and an inability to sit still for more than a short period of time. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use.
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: It usually occurs within 10 days of starting neuroleptic therapy. Clinical manifestations include fever, encephalopathy, muscle rigidity, dystonia, diaphoresis, tachycardia and labile blood pressure. Treatment is with dantrolene or with dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine.
  • Tardive dyskinesia: It is characterized by involuntary, choreoathetoid movements in patients treated with antipsychotic medications. This disorder would be unlikely to occur within a few days of the initiation of drug therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following protein defect is not seen in the condition suggested by the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows numerous spherocytes which are characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis. Laminin is not involved in the pathogenesis of hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by inherited defects in the proteins stabilizing the red cell membrane.

Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane.

This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The nondeformable spherocytes are trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

 

Note: 

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS: Autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal dominant HS: Ankyrin > Band 3
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal recessive HS: Spectrin
  • Most severe form of HS: Spectrin (recessive)

questions.text: All of the following are components of the GOBI FFF strategy except:
questions.solution:
The GOBI FFF strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF, originally known as United Nations Internation Children’s Emergency Fund).

Components of GOBI FFF are given in the pearl mentioned below.

Related Pearl: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

  • G – Growth monitoring with growth charts
  • O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration
  • B – Breastfeeding
  • I – Immunization of children
  • F – Family planning and birth spacing
  • F – Food supplementation
  • F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: Identify the cataract shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows sutural cataract with Y shaped anterior suture and inverted Y shaped posterior suture opacifications. The sutural opacities are located in the nucleus of the lens and cause little visual disturbance. Surgery is not usually required.

Other options:

Zonular cataract is an opaque ring usually seen in the foetal nucleus of the lens. The ring is formed by defective lens fibres produced during a particular period of development. Other lens fibres are normal. It accounts for about half of all visually significant congenital cataracts.

Coronary cataracts are club-shaped peripheral opacities present in the deep cortex and the superficial nucleus of the lens. They are not progressive and don’t usually affect vision.

Fusiform cataracts are spindle-shaped anteroposterior cataracts that have a genetic association and run in families. They are also called spindle-shaped, axial or coralliform cataracts. They may be associated with polar cataracts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was brought to the psychiatric OPD by her friend. The patient claims that her boss is in love with her and stalks her. The woman’s friend refutes her claims. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erotomania is a delusional disorder where the patient believes someone is in love with him/her, against evidence to the contrary. It is also known as De Clérambault syndrome.

The lover in the delusion is often a person of higher social status. It is more common in women.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A junior resident, during his first emergency room duty, comes across a patient with difficulty in breathing. Since he was not confident to do endotracheal intubation, He tries to secure the airway with the following device. All of the following are the advantages associated with the use of this device when compared with tracheal intubation except:
questions.solution:
This given image is of Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA). The disadvantage associated with its use is that there is an increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration when compared with tracheal intubation.

The laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that sits in the hypopharynx and partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions, but not gastric regurgitation.

Advantages and disadvantages of the laryngeal mask airway compared with tracheal intubation are: 

Advantages:

  • Easy and rapid
  • Less invasive
  • Better hemodynamic stability
  • Very useful in difficult intubations
  • Less tooth and laryngeal trauma
  • Does not require muscle relaxation
  • Does not require neck mobility 
  • No risk of esophageal or endobronchial intubation

Disadvantages:

  • Increased risk of gastrointestinal aspiration
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of gas leak and pollution
  • Can cause gastric distention

questions.text: Which of the following is the pre-trematic nerve of first pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Chorda tympani is the pre-trematic nerve of the first pharyngeal arch.

Nerve supply of Pharyngeal arches:

The nerve of the arch itself runs along the cranial side of the arch and is called post-trematic nerve of the arch.

Each arch also receives a branch from the nerve of the succeeding arch called the pre-trematic nerve which runs along the caudal border of the arch.

The mandibular nerve is the post-trematic nerve of the first arch and chorda tympani (branch of the facial nerve) is the pre-trematic nerve.

This double innervation is reflected in the nerve supply of anterior two-thirds of tongue which is derived from the first arch.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the image given below ?

choices.text: Most common manifestation of nail psoriasis
Most specific sign of nail psoriasis
Most common manifestation of Lichen Planus of the nail
Most specific sign of Lichen Planus of the nail

questions.solution:
The above clinical image depicting Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus.

The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

 

Related Pearl: Nail changes in lichen planus

Nail involvement in lichen planus occurs in up to 10% of the cases but is usually a minor feature of the disease.

Dorsal Nail Pterygium is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. The fusion of dorsal nail fold and nail bed leads to pterygium.

The most frequent nail change is the exaggeration of longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to a slight thinning of the nail plate.

Pup-tent sign - elevation of nail in shape of tent

Trachonychia - 20 nail dystrophy

Subungual Hyperkeratosis and Onycholysis

Longitudinal Melanonychia in Lichen Planus of the nail bed

Permanent destruction of several toenails with ulceration of soles (rare variant)

Image shows  Nails in Lichen planus presented with irregular longitudinal grooves and ridges .

Image : Dorsal Nail Pterygium

Image : Pup-tent sign 

Image : Trachonychia

questions.text: Identify the type of MRI image given below.
questions.solution:
The MRI image given above is T1 weighted.

In T1 images CSF is dark/hypointense and white matter is white whereas In T2 images CSF is bright/hyperintense and white matter is dark.

Other options:

  • In FLAIR images CSF and white matter is dark.
  • FLAIR (fluid attenuated inversion recovery) is an inversion recovery technique that nulls fluid.
  • STIR (Short tau inversion recovery) is done to detect bone marrow oedema.

FLAIR:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with bleeding per rectum. He gives a history of lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and return spontaneously thereafter. The degree of hemorrhoids would be:
questions.solution:
Lumps that appear at the anal orifice during defaecation and which return spontaneously afterwards indicate second degree haemorrhoids.

Four degrees of haemorrhoids:

First degree – bleed only, no prolapse

Second degree – prolapse but reduce spontaneously

Third degree – prolapse and have to be manually reduced

Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

questions.text: Which test is being performed below?
questions.solution:
Thomas test is being performed in the given image. 

Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. 

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered as a positive test as normally this is not possible. 

Other options: 

  • Trendelenburg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of gluteus medius muscle. 
  • Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band. 
  • Allen's test is mainly used to test the adequacy of ulnar collateral blood flow to the hand, which is usually done prior to radial artery cannulation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presented with neurological symptoms. The radiological image is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple FLAIR hyperintense lesions arranged perpendicular to the lateral ventricles in a triangular configuration (Dawson's fingers) is typical for multiple sclerosis.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is the most common immune-mediated inflammatory demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. It is the second most common cause of neurological impairment in young adults, after trauma.

MS is characterized pathologically by multifocal areas of demyelination with the loss of oligodendrocytes and astroglial scarring.

Dawson fingers are a radiographic feature depicting demyelinating plaques through the corpus callosum, arranged at right angles along medullary veins (callososeptal location). They are relatively specific signs for multiple sclerosis (MS), which presents as T2 hyperintensities.

The arrow in the below image show's the Dawson fingers:

Related Pearl: The 2017 Revised McDonald Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Sclerosis

Clinical
(Attacks)		 Objective
Lesions		 Additional requirements to make the diagnosis
2 or more 2 or more None*
2 or more 1 None*
2 or more 1 Dissemination in space demonstrated by an additional clinical attack implicating a different CNS site or by MRI
 1  2 or more

Dissemination in time demonstrated by an additional clinical attack or by MRI

or demonstration of CSF-specific oligoclonal bands
 1

 1

Dissemination in space demonstrated by an additional clinical attack implicating a different CNS site or by MRI

AND

Dissemination in time demonstrated by an additional clinical attack or by MRI OR demonstration of CSF-specific oligoclonal bands
    * No additional test needed. MRI considered in all cases. Spinal cord MRI or CSF examination in patients with insufficient clinical diagnosis

 

Definition of MRI evidence of
dissemination in space		 T2 lesion in at least 2 of 4 MS-typical regions (peri-ventricular, juxtocortical, infratentorial,
or spinal cord)
Note: Gd-enhancing lesions are not required
Definition of MRI evidence of
dissemination in time		 The simultaneous presence of Gd-enhancing and non-enhancing MRI lesions at any time
New T2 and/or Gd-enhancing lesion(s) on follow-up MRI

Gd, gadolinium; MS, multiple sclerosis
